sen.j: 草履（ぞうり）は、日本の伝統的な履物の一つ。
sen.e: Zori is a type of Japanese traditional footwear.
Zori are a sandal-like type of Japanese traditional footwear.
Zori are a sandal-like type of Japanese traditional footwear.

sen.j: 明治時代以降に靴が普及するまで、日本で広く使用されていた。
sen.e: Zori were worn widely in Japan until shoes became widespread in the Meiji period and afterwards.
Zori were worn widely in Japan until shoes became widespread following the Meiji Restoration in the mid-ninteenth century.

sen.e: Zori were worn widely in Japan until shoes became widespread following the Meiji Restoration in the mid-nineteenth century.

sen.j: 現代日本においては主に和装時に履く。
sen.e: In modern Japan, zori are primarily worn when dressed in kimono (Japanese traditional clothing).

sen.j: 下駄よりも格式があり、改まった履物とされる。
sen.e: Zori are considered more formal than geta (Japanese footwear, wooden clogs).

sen.j: 草履の種類はいくつかあるが、現代では「革草履」が主流である。
sen.e: There are several types of zori, and today kawa zori (Japanese footwear sandals made of leather) is the most popular among them.

sen.j: 男性用・女性用とも革、布、ビニール、などで覆われた小判型の靴底（ソール）に同種の表をつけ、鼻緒を据える。
sen.e: Zori for both men and women are made with an ellipse- or oval-shaped soles covered by leather, cloth or vinyl (plastic), attached with the similar materials on the surface and a hanao (strap or thong).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Zori for both men and women are made with ellipse- or oval-shaped soles covered with leather, cloth or vinyl (plastic), with an insole of similar material and a thong known as a hanao.

sen.j: 靴底の素材は良質のコルク製であったが、和装の衰退にともない安価なウレタンにとって代わられた。
sen.e: In past days, high-quality cork was used as material for the sole, but as the tradition of wearing kimino fell out, it was replaced with inexpensive urethane.

sen.j: 正装で用いられるような高級品は底を重ねて厚みを持たせてあり、「何枚草履」などと呼んだ。
sen.e: High-quality zori worn with formal attire had thick soles made by putting several soles together, which was called 'nanmai zori'.
High-quality zori worn with formal attire had thick soles made by putting several soles together and were called 'nanmai zori'.

sen.j: 地面と接する底裏の部分は硬質のウレタンゴムが貼られる。
sen.e: The back side of the sole which makes contact with the ground surface is covered with hard urethane rubber.
The outsole, which makes contact with the ground, is covered with hard urethane rubber.

sen.j: 畳の材料であるイグサ素材を編んだ古風な「畳表草履」は、歌舞伎などの舞台用か、ごく一部の男性用として見かける程度に過ぎず、現代では廃れてしまった。
sen.e: Tatami omote zori (zori whose upper covering of the sole is made of tatami, soft rush knitted) are only seen in such occasions as in kabuki stages or worn by only a few men; they fell into disuse.
These days, tatami omote zori with insoles made of bulrush and resembling tatami mats are quite rare; they are only seen in kabuki or occasionally being worn by some men.

sen.j: 男性用で、厚みのない台の裏に牛革やウレタンゴムを張り、鼻緒を据えた四角い草履を雪駄という。
sen.e: A type of square-shaped zori for men which has a thin sole covered with bull leather or urethane rubber on the back and attached with hanao is called setta.
Setta are a type of thin-soled square-shaped zori for men, with an outsole of bull leather or urethane rubber and a hanao.

sen.j: また、草履に似た形状で布や藁を素材とし、後部に足首に固定するための結び紐を付けた履物は草鞋（わらじ）と呼び、古くは労働などの日常作業用の履物として普及した。
sen.e: Also, a footwear which is a zori-looking shape and made of cloth or straw, attached with a strap around the heel part to fix the footwear to the ankle was called waraji, and popularly worn in day to day work.
Also, footwear similar to zori and made of cloth or straw, with a strap on the heel to fix it to the ankle was called waraji, and was commonly worn in day to day work.

sen.j: 最近では、使い古した布地を再利用するため、また室内で鼻緒付の履物を取り入れるためスリッパに代わる存在として、手作りの「布ぞうり」を製作する人が増えている。
sen.e: Nowadays, in order to recycle used cloth and to wear indoor footwear that has hanao for a replacement with slippers, more and more people make handmade nuno (cloth) zori.
Nowadays, in order to recycle used cloth and to wear indoor footwear with a hanao instead of slippers, more and more people make handmade cloth zori.

sen.j: あくまで室内履きであるが、鼻緒の効用として注目されつつある。
sen.e: Although these are just indoor footwear, but they are gaining attention for the function of hanao.
Although these are just indoor footwear, they are gaining attention for the benefits of the hanao.

sen.j: 最近では鼻緒付きの履物が足の鍛練に効果があるという意見から、子供らに下駄や草履をはかせることが注目されている。
sen.e: Due to the idea that footwear with hanao have an effect of strengthening legs, having kids to wear geta or zori are attracting attentions.
Due to the idea that footwear with hanao is beneficial for development of the legs, having kids wear geta or zori is attracting attention.

sen.j: 鼻緒を挟み、台を踏ん張るため足の筋肉が鍛えられ足裏の土踏まずの形成や外反母趾の予防にもよいとされる。
sen.e: Wearing geta and zori are thought to strengthen the leg muscles, help to form plantar arch, and prevent hallux valgus, because one must pinch the hanao and hold on the zori.
Since the hanao must be gripped between the toes to hold on to the zori, they are thought to be good for strengthening leg muscles, forming the arch of the foot and preventing bunions.

sen.j: はだし教育として幼稚園・保育園・小学校などの施設で指定の履物にするところもある。
sen.e: Some kindergartens, day nurseries, and elementary schools prescribe the children and students to wear zori as a part of barefoot life.
sen.cmt: 用語共有にHadashi kyoiku (Barefoot life)とありましたが、特にローマ字表記する必要もないかと思い、英語表記のみにしました。

sen.j: 学校納入用では奈良県の三郷町で生産される製品、健康草履「ミサトっ子」がある。
sen.e: As zori for kids in schools, zori named 'misatokko' are produced in Misato-machi, Nara prefecture.
Zori for schoolchildren are manufactured in Misato-machi, Nara Prefecture under the name "Misatokko".

sen.j: 基本的に素足で履くことが多く、足が蒸れないという効用もある。
sen.e: Usually zori are worn barefoot and so one does not have to worry about sweaty feet.
Usually zori are worn without socks, so one does not have to worry about sweaty feet.

sen.j: また、靴底の厚い高いスニーカーなどは草履に比べ履いた時の安定性が悪く、更に底が不均一に磨耗した場合、より傾きX脚やO脚,「ハの字」や「Vの字（逆ハの字）」歩きを誘発したり悪循環を助長すると考えられている。
sen.e: Wearing sneakers with thick soles are unstable compared to zori, and if the sole is worn out unevenly, those shoes become more unstable, resulting in or worsening knock-knees, bow-legs, being hen-toed, or duck-footed.

Sneakers with thick soles provide less stability than zori, and if the sole is worn out unevenly, they become even less stable, resulting in or worsening knock-knees, bow-legs, being hen-toed, or duck-footed.

sen.e: Zori are better to stabilize and strengthen physique or to form beautiful legs than converted and advanced footwear like sneakers.
Zori are better at providing stability and strengthening physique or forming beautiful legs than modern footwear like sneakers.

sen.e: Today there are a lot more children who fall over quite often, cannot keep standing for a long time, or easy to get tired by walking.

sen.j: 江戸時代に造られていた金剛草履（堅くて丈夫な草履という意味）は、2束で3文という売られ方をされていたことから、安価や投げ売りという意味で二束三文という言葉が生まれている。
sen.e: Since kongo zori (big and durable Japanese footwear sandals) made in the Edo period were sold at three mon (an old currency unit in Japan) for two pairs of zori, the saying 'nisokusanmon' (three mon for two pairs, meaning dirt cheap) came about.

Kongo zori (strong, durable zori) made in the Edo Period (1603-1868) were sold at three mon (an old unit of currency) for two pairs, giving rise to the expression 'nisokusanmon' (two pairs for three mon), meaning dirt cheap.
